content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Madeline Jensen: I was born in Charleston, South Carolina, and grew up in a small, tight-knit neighborhood where everyone knew each other. My parents were both well-educated—my father had a graduate degree in engineering, and my mother had a bachelor's in education. They worked hard, and we had a comfortable life, though things changed when my parents divorced when I was around twelve. I remember feeling like the world shifted overnight. My mother moved to a different part of the state for a teaching job, and I had to adjust to a new school, new friends, and a new routine. It wasn't easy, but I learned to be independent early on. I excelled in school, especially in the sciences, and I was always curious about how things worked. I ended up earning a bachelor's degree in environmental science, which I thought would lead me to a stable career. But after graduation, the job market wasn't as promising as I had hoped, and I found myself laid off after a short stint at a local nonprofit. I've been looking for work ever since, and while it's been challenging, I've used this time to explore other interests—like learning Spanish, which I've always wanted to do, and volunteering in my community. Life hasn't gone exactly as I planned, but I'm still hopeful and trying to stay positive.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Madeline Jensen: One of those crossroads came right after I graduated from college. I had two main options: take a job with a small environmental consulting firm in Charleston or move to a bigger city for a graduate program in sustainable development. I was torn because the job would have given me immediate experience and stability, but the graduate program felt like the more long-term investment in my career. I chose the graduate program, thinking it would open more doors and give me the tools to make a real impact in the field. But halfway through my first semester, I realized I was struggling to keep up with the pace and the pressure of the program, and I missed the hands-on work I had done in my undergraduate studies. I ended up dropping out and returning to Charleston, which was a hard decision. It felt like a failure at the time, but looking back, it was the right choice for me. It forced me to reevaluate what I wanted from my career and gave me the time to explore other interests, like volunteering and learning Spanish. That experience taught me that sometimes the path that seems less conventional can lead to the most meaningful growth.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Madeline Jensen: I think it was a mix of both, honestly. There was a conscious decision to drop out, but there were also a lot of external factors that made it feel like the right time. I was overwhelmed, and I wasn't enjoying the program the way I thought I would. It wasn't just about making a choice—it was about realizing that I needed to take a step back and reassess what I truly wanted. I remember sitting in my dorm room one night, staring at my textbooks, and just feeling this deep sense of disconnection. I didn't want to be in a place where I felt like I was just going through the motions. So, I made the decision to leave, but it also felt like something inside me was pushing me to do it. I think that's what makes life so complex—sometimes the choices we make are a combination of what we want and what we need, even if we don't fully understand it at the time.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Madeline Jensen: Absolutely, I think having someone to talk to during that time would have made a huge difference. I was pretty stubborn about handling everything on my own, which probably made things harder than they needed to be. If I had reached out to a counselor or even a mentor, maybe I could have worked through some of the doubts I was feeling instead of just shutting down. I remember thinking that I had to prove to myself that I could handle the pressure, but in reality, I was just trying to do it all alone. Looking back, I wish I had been more open to support—whether it was from friends, family, or professionals. It's something I've tried to be more aware of since then, both for myself and for others who might be going through similar struggles.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Madeline Jensen: I don't have a partner or children right now, though I've had a few serious relationships over the years. After my parents' divorce, I became pretty focused on my studies and career, and I think that made it harder to build lasting connections. I've dated a few people since college, but none of them really stuck around. I'm not sure if it's because I was still figuring out who I was or if I just hadn't met the right person yet. My mother and I stay in touch, and we talk pretty regularly. She's been a big support system for me, especially during the time I was laid off. I also have a few close friends from college who I keep in contact with, and we meet up whenever we can. Family and friends are really important to me, even if I don't always show it. I think I've learned that it's okay to ask for help and to lean on the people who care about you—especially after going through some tough times on my own.

Going through the interview questions made me reflect on how much my life has changed over the years. Starting from my childhood in Charleston, to the challenges of my parents' divorce, my education, and the crossroads I faced after college, each experience has shaped who I am today. It was hard to admit that I dropped out of graduate school, but looking back, it was the right decision for me. I've learned that sometimes the paths we take aren't the ones we expect, but they can lead to unexpected growth. I also realize now how important it is to lean on others during tough times, rather than trying to handle everything alone. Even though I don't have a partner or children right now, my family and friends remain a big part of my life, and I'm grateful for their support. Overall, these reflections have helped me understand my journey better and appreciate the resilience I've shown along the way.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Madeline Jensen: My father is still in Charleston, though we don't talk as often as I'd like. He's always been a bit reserved, especially after the divorce. I think he still feels like he missed out on a lot of my life, and I can't blame him for that. I try to reach out now and then, but it's always a bit awkward. I know he's proud of me in his own way, even if he doesn't always show it. My sister, on the other hand, is someone I talk to more regularly. She's a few years younger than me and lives in Atlanta now. She's a nurse, which I think is amazing—she's always been the more driven one of us. We don't see each other as much as I'd like, but when we do, it's like no time has passed. She's been there for me through a lot of the tough times, and I really appreciate that. I guess my family isn't perfect, but they've all played a role in shaping who I am, even if we don't always get along.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Madeline Jensen: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been really important to me over the years. One of them is Sarah, who I met in college. We were in the same environmental science program, and we bonded over our shared passion for sustainability. Even though we went different paths after graduation—she ended up working for a nonprofit focused on clean energy, while I took a different route—she's always been someone I can count on. We still keep in touch, and she's been a great source of encouragement, especially when I was struggling after being laid off. Then there's Marcus, a friend from high school who I reconnected with a few years ago. He's a musician, and he's helped me stay grounded by reminding me of the importance of creativity and joy in life. I think it's easy to get caught up in the pressures of work and responsibilities, but people like Sarah and Marcus help me remember that there's more to life than just the daily grind. They've been there for me during tough times, and I'm grateful for their presence in my life.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Madeline Jensen: I live in a quiet neighborhood just a few blocks away from downtown Charleston. It's a mix of old and new—there are historic homes with beautiful architecture, but also some newer apartments and condos that have been built in recent years. The area is pretty walkable, which I appreciate, and there are a lot of local shops, cafes, and parks nearby. I live in a small apartment on the second floor of a building that was originally built in the early 1900s. It's not much, but it's cozy and has a lot of character. I love how close I am to the waterfront, and I often take walks along the Battery or sit by the harbor and watch the boats go by. It's a peaceful place, and even though I've been through some tough times, I find comfort in the rhythm of everyday life here. The people in the neighborhood are friendly, and I've made a few new friends through local events and community groups. It's not the same as the tight-knit neighborhood I grew up in, but there's still a sense of community that I really value.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Madeline Jensen: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. It's not the kind of place where I worry about walking home at night or locking my door twice. There's a real sense of community, and even though I don't know everyone by name, I feel like people look out for each other. I've never had any issues with crime or anything like that, which is something I appreciate, especially after growing up in a neighborhood where safety was always a concern. I think part of it is the slower pace of life here—people are more connected to their surroundings and to each other. It's not perfect, of course, but I feel like I can live here without constantly being on edge, which is a relief after some of the stress I've been through.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Madeline Jensen: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. The biggest upside is the sense of calm and connection I feel with the place. I love being able to walk to the market, the coffee shop, or the library without needing a car. It makes life feel simpler, and I've found that simplicity helps me stay grounded, especially when I'm feeling uncertain about my job search. On the downside, sometimes the pace can feel a bit slow, and I've caught myself longing for more opportunities or challenges. I know that's just me wanting to grow, but it can be frustrating when I feel like I'm not making progress. Still, I've learned to appreciate the little things—the sound of the waves, the smell of fresh-baked bread from the bakery down the street, the way the neighborhood feels like a small town even in a big city. It's not perfect, but it's home, and I've come to see that home is about more than just where you live—it's about the peace you find there.

Going through the interview questions about my family, relationships, and current neighborhood made me reflect on how much my support system has shaped my life, even when I wasn't always aware of it. Talking about my parents, especially my father and sister, reminded me of how family dynamics can be complicated but still deeply influential. It also made me realize how much I've relied on my friends and the sense of community in my current neighborhood, even when I've struggled with loneliness or uncertainty. I think it's important to acknowledge the people who have been there for me, even if we don't always stay in close contact. The questions also made me appreciate how safe and comforting my current home feels, which is something I hadn't really stopped to think about until now. It's a reminder that even in the midst of life's challenges, there are still things to be grateful for.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Madeline Jensen: A typical week for me is pretty fluid, but there's a rhythm to it. I usually start my week with a few days of job searching—applying to positions, networking, and sometimes volunteering at a local community center. I find that volunteering helps me stay connected and gives me a sense of purpose, even when things feel uncertain. Midweek, I try to make time for self-care—maybe a yoga class, a walk by the harbor, or just reading a book. I also meet up with Sarah or Marcus for coffee or a meal, which is important for keeping my spirits up. On the weekends, I like to explore the area a bit more—visiting local markets, attending a small art show, or just relaxing at home with a movie. I've also been taking Spanish classes online, so I try to set aside some time each week for that. It's not always easy to stay motivated, but I've learned to embrace the small routines that keep me grounded. I think that's what living here has taught me—how to find peace in the everyday, even when the bigger picture feels unclear.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Madeline Jensen: Right now, I'm not working a traditional job, which feels both uncertain and freeing in its own way. I've been applying to a variety of positions—some in environmental advocacy, others in community outreach or administrative roles. The job search has been slow, and there are days when I feel like I'm just going through the motions, but I try to remind myself that I'm still learning and growing. I've also been volunteering part-time at a local community center, which gives me a sense of purpose and keeps me connected to the people around me. It's not a paid position, but it's meaningful work—helping with literacy programs for kids and organizing small workshops on sustainability. I usually volunteer on weekends or afternoons when I have free time. It's not the career I originally imagined for myself, but it's something I can be proud of, and it keeps me active and engaged with the community I care about.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Madeline Jensen: Outside of work and volunteering, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay balanced. I try to cook most nights, even if it's just a simple meal—there's something grounding about preparing food for myself. I've also taken up journaling again, which I hadn't done in a while. It helps me process my thoughts, especially when I'm feeling stuck or uncertain. I also make sure to set aside time for my Spanish lessons, even if it's just 30 minutes a day. It's been a fun challenge, and I've started to feel more confident in my ability to communicate in another language. I think these small habits—cooking, writing, learning—help me stay focused and remind me that I'm still moving forward, even if it's not in the way I originally planned.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Madeline Jensen: One of the more recent changes to my routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my day. I started with short meditation sessions in the morning, something I used to avoid because I thought it was too 'new age' or not practical for someone like me. But after a particularly stressful week of job applications and feeling stuck in a loop of uncertainty, I decided to give it a try. Now, I set my alarm five minutes earlier and spend those minutes just breathing and grounding myself. It's helped me start the day with a bit more clarity, even if it's just for a few minutes. I've also been trying to be more intentional about my sleep schedule, going to bed and waking up at the same time each day. It's not perfect, but these small shifts have made a noticeable difference in how I feel overall. I think part of it is just learning to be kinder to myself, especially during this time of transition. I'm still figuring out what works best, but I'm grateful for the little changes that help me feel more centered.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Madeline Jensen: I don't have children, but I can imagine what it might be like based on the people I know. If I did, I think a typical weekday during the school year would involve a lot of structure—mornings filled with breakfast, getting ready for school, and maybe a quick walk or some quiet time before heading out. After school, there would be homework, extracurricular activities like sports or music lessons, and then family time in the evening. I think it would be beautiful to have that kind of rhythm, to be part of a child's growth and to watch them explore the world. I've seen friends who are parents, and while it's a huge responsibility, it also seems incredibly rewarding. I can only hope that if I ever have children, I can provide them with the same sense of security and support that I've been lucky to have in my own life.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my support system and daily routines have shaped my current sense of self. Talking about my family, friends, and neighborhood reminded me of the importance of connection, even when life feels uncertain. It also made me realize how much I've come to rely on small, consistent routines—like cooking, journaling, and learning Spanish—to keep me grounded. I've always thought of myself as independent, but these conversations helped me see that leaning on others and finding comfort in everyday habits are just as vital as the big decisions we make. It's a reminder that even when things don't go as planned, there's still value in the little things that help us stay centered and hopeful.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Madeline Jensen: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm generally in decent shape, though I've had my share of ups and downs. I used to be pretty active in college, running a few times a week and participating in outdoor clubs, but after I dropped out of graduate school, I got a bit more sedentary. I've been trying to get back into a routine, especially with the mindfulness and yoga I mentioned earlier. I also started going for daily walks along the waterfront, which has helped me both physically and mentally. I do have some chronic issues with anxiety, which I think is tied to the uncertainty of my job search and the pressure I've put on myself to have everything figured out. I've been seeing a therapist occasionally, which has been helpful in learning how to manage that. I also take care of my mental health by staying connected with friends and family, and by making time for things I enjoy, like cooking, reading, and learning Spanish. I think it's important to be honest about the struggles, but also to recognize the progress I've made. I'm not where I want to be yet, but I'm working on it—one step at a time.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Madeline Jensen: For me, staying healthy is a mix of what makes it easy and what makes it hard. On the easy side, living in a place where I can walk almost everywhere helps a lot. I don't have to rely on a car, which means I'm more likely to get outside, move my body, and stay connected to the rhythm of the day. Also, having a routine—like my morning walks or yoga sessions—gives me something to look forward to, even on days when I don't feel like it. But on the harder side, the uncertainty of my job search can really take a toll on my mental health. There are days when I feel stuck in a loop of applying and not getting anywhere, and that weighs on me. It's hard to stay motivated when I don't have the structure of a regular job. I also struggle with consistency—sometimes I fall into a pattern of staying up too late, skipping meals, or not taking the time to care for myself the way I know I should. But I'm learning that small, consistent efforts matter more than perfection. It's not always easy, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself and recognize that staying healthy is a process, not a destination.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Madeline Jensen: In the past two years, I've dealt with some flare-ups of my anxiety, especially during the height of the job search when it felt like I was going in circles without any real progress. There were a few weeks where I was struggling to get out of bed, and I had to really push myself to keep going. I also started experiencing some mild back pain, probably from sitting too long while applying for jobs or volunteering. I didn't think much of it at first, but it got worse over time, so I finally made an appointment with a physical therapist. They said it was mostly due to poor posture and lack of movement, which makes sense given how much I've been sitting. I've been working on strengthening exercises and trying to be more mindful of how I sit and move throughout the day. It's been a reminder that my health isn't just about my mental state—it's also about taking care of my body, even in small ways. I've learned that I can't ignore the physical signs when something's off, and I'm trying to be more proactive about my well-being now.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Madeline Jensen: I think my health challenges have definitely affected my ability to work as consistently as I'd like, especially during the worst of the anxiety flare-ups. There were times when I felt so overwhelmed that I couldn't even bring myself to apply for jobs, let alone focus on anything else. It's frustrating because I know I have the skills and the drive, but sometimes my mind just gets stuck in a loop of self-doubt. I also had to adjust my volunteering schedule a few times when my back pain was at its worst, which was hard because I really value that connection with the community. But honestly, those experiences have taught me a lot about patience and self-compassion. I've learned that it's okay to take a step back when I need to, and that healing—whether mental or physical—is a process that can't be rushed. I'm still working on it, but I'm trying to be more gentle with myself and recognize that progress, even if it's slow, is still progress.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Madeline Jensen: Over the past year, I've had a lot of mixed emotions—some days feeling like I'm making progress, and others feeling like I'm just spinning my wheels. There have been moments of hope, like when I landed a few interviews or got positive feedback on my applications, but there have also been a lot of rejections and days where I felt like I wasn't good enough. I've been trying to be more patient with myself, though, and I've started to notice small wins—like finally mastering a Spanish phrase or feeling more confident in my ability to connect with others. I've also been working on my mental health more consistently, going to therapy regularly and practicing mindfulness in the mornings. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that it's okay to have bad days and that healing isn't linear. I've also found comfort in my community, whether it's through volunteering, meeting up with friends, or just walking along the waterfront and feeling the rhythm of the city. I think I'm in a better place than I was a year ago, even if it doesn't always feel that way. I'm still figuring things out, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself and trust that things will work out in their own time.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my daily routines and health have shaped my sense of stability and well-being. Talking about my mindfulness practices, sleep schedule, and the challenges of staying healthy reminded me of how small, intentional changes can make a big difference in how I feel. It also made me realize how deeply my mental health is tied to my job search and the uncertainty that comes with it. I've always thought of myself as independent, but these conversations helped me see that taking care of myself—both physically and emotionally—is just as important as the big decisions I've made in life. I'm still learning, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made, even if it's not always easy.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Madeline Jensen: I think I've struggled with anxiety more than anything else, especially over the past few years. It's not the kind of anxiety that comes from a specific event, but more of a constant undercurrent of worry—about my future, my ability to find work, and whether I'm making the right choices. There were times when I felt like I was failing at everything, like I wasn't good enough or that I had missed my chance to build the life I wanted. I've had moments where I felt so overwhelmed that I couldn't even get out of bed, and I had to force myself to do the simplest things, like making a cup of coffee or going for a walk. I've been seeing a therapist for the past few months, and that's been really helpful in learning how to manage those feelings. I've also started journaling more, which helps me process my thoughts and see patterns in how I react to stress. I don't think I've ever officially been diagnosed with depression, but I know that anxiety has been a constant companion for me. What I've learned is that it's okay to not be okay, and that taking small steps—like talking to someone, going for a walk, or just breathing deeply—can make a big difference. I'm still learning how to live with it, but I'm trying to be more compassionate with myself and to recognize that my worth isn't tied to my productivity or my ability to find a job.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Madeline Jensen: For my family, it's been a mix of support and concern, especially with how things have been for me over the past few years. My mother has been the most consistent source of encouragement—she's always believed in me, even when I didn't believe in myself. She's been there to listen when I needed to vent, and she's never made me feel like I was a burden. My sister, on the other hand, has been more hands-on. She's actually helped me with my job search a few times, sending me leads or even introducing me to people in her network. She's always been the more driven one, so it's kind of funny that she's the one who's been pushing me to get back on my feet. My father, though, has been more distant. I think he still feels like he missed out on a lot of my life after the divorce, and I can't blame him for that. We don't talk as much as I'd like, but when we do, it's always awkward. Still, I know he cares, even if he doesn't always show it. Overall, I'm grateful for the support I've received from my family, even if it hasn't always been easy. They've all played a role in helping me get through this time, and I hope I can be there for them in return when they need it.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Madeline Jensen: I think religion or spirituality hasn't played a big role in my life, though I was raised in a Protestant household. My mother was pretty active in church growing up, and I remember going to Sunday school and attending services with her. But as I got older, I started to question a lot of the beliefs I was taught, and I found myself moving away from organized religion. I don't think of myself as spiritual in the traditional sense, but I do find meaning in the small, everyday moments—like the way the sunlight hits the water in the morning, or the quiet comfort of a good book. I think I've come to see spirituality as something more personal and less about following a specific set of rules or doctrines. I'm not sure if that makes me an atheist or just someone who's still figuring things out, but I feel more at peace with not having all the answers than I ever did with pretending I did.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Madeline Jensen: I don't use social media all that much, honestly. I know it's a big part of how people stay connected these days, but I've always found it a bit overwhelming. There's something about scrolling through endless posts and comparing your life to others that just doesn't sit well with me. I tried using Facebook a few years back to stay in touch with old classmates and family, but it felt more like a chore than a way to connect. Instagram, in particular, always made me feel like I was missing out on something—like everyone else was living this exciting, curated life while I was just trying to figure things out. I've been more intentional about how I use technology lately, so I limit my time on these platforms and focus more on real, face-to-face interactions. I do follow a few environmental blogs and Spanish learning accounts, just to keep myself inspired, but I'm not someone who needs to be constantly online. I think I've learned that staying connected doesn't always have to happen through a screen—it can be as simple as a phone call, a message, or even just showing up for someone when they need you.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Madeline Jensen: Honestly, I don't think I've ever really relied on social media for support during tough times. I know a lot of people find comfort in sharing their struggles online or getting advice from others who've been through similar things, but I've always been more of a private person. I prefer talking things out one-on-one, whether it's with a friend, my mother, or even a therapist. I think there's something about seeing someone's pain filtered through a screen that makes it feel less real, or at least less immediate. That said, I do appreciate the way social media can connect people to resources or communities they might not have access to otherwise. I've followed a few environmental groups and mental health advocates online, and sometimes their posts remind me that I'm not alone in what I'm going through. But for the most part, I've found that the real support comes from the people I know in person, not the ones I follow on a phone.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how deeply my health and emotional well-being have been intertwined with the challenges I've faced over the past year. Talking about my anxiety, the physical pain I've experienced, and how it's affected my ability to work reminded me of how much I've been carrying without always realizing it. It also made me think about how important it is to acknowledge those struggles, even if they don't always have clear solutions. I've been learning that healing isn't about fixing everything overnight—it's about showing up for myself, even on the hardest days. I'm still figuring out how to balance the pressure of finding work with taking care of my mind and body, but I'm trying to be more patient with the process. I've come to accept that it's okay to not be okay, and that small steps—like going to therapy, practicing mindfulness, or just talking to someone—can make a real difference. These conversations have helped me see that my worth isn't tied to my productivity or my ability to find a job, and that's something I need to keep reminding myself of, especially when the doubts creep in.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Madeline Jensen: In the past few months, I've noticed that my stress levels have actually decreased a bit, which is something I didn't expect. It's not that things have gotten easier—finding work is still a challenge—but I've started to feel more at peace with the process. I think part of it is the small changes I've made in my daily life, like the morning meditation and the more consistent sleep schedule. I've also been practicing self-compassion more, which has helped me let go of some of the self-criticism I used to carry around. When I feel worried or overwhelmed, I've started using a technique I learned in therapy—writing down my thoughts and then physically tearing the paper up as a way to release the weight of them. It sounds silly, but it really does help. I've also found that staying connected with friends and family, even in small ways, has made a big difference in how I handle stress. I used to think I had to handle everything on my own, but now I realize that asking for support doesn't make me weak—it just makes me human.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Madeline Jensen: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and utilities. I live in a small apartment, so the rent is manageable, but it still takes up a good chunk of my monthly income. I've been relying on savings from when I was working at the nonprofit, and I also get some income from the volunteer work I do at the community center—though it's not enough to cover everything. Groceries have been a bit tight, especially since I've been trying to eat more healthfully and cook at home instead of eating out. I've also been paying for my Spanish classes online, which is another expense I hadn't anticipated. To make ends meet, I've been careful with my spending—using coupons, buying in bulk when I can, and avoiding unnecessary purchases. I also get some financial support from my mother when things get really tight, which I'm grateful for, but I know I can't rely on that forever. It's been a balancing act, but I've learned to be more mindful of where my money goes and to prioritize what's truly important.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Madeline Jensen: To be honest, my monthly spending has been a bit all over the place lately. Some months I'm able to stick to a strict budget, and others, especially when I'm feeling down or overwhelmed, I end up spending more on things like takeout or small indulgences just to feel better. Last month, I think I spent around $1,800, which is actually a bit higher than usual. That was partly because I had to replace my laptop after it stopped working, and I also bought a few new books for my Spanish classes. Normally, I try to keep it around $1,500 to $1,600, with most of that going to rent, groceries, and utilities. I've been trying to track my expenses more carefully using a simple spreadsheet, which has helped me see where I'm overspending. I also try to set aside a small amount each month for unexpected costs, just in case. It's not perfect, but it's a start. I know I need to be more disciplined, especially as I continue to search for work, but I'm learning that managing money is just another part of the journey—something I have to keep working on, just like everything else in life.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Madeline Jensen: We rent our home. I live in a small apartment on the second floor of a historic building in Charleston. It's not much, but it's affordable and has a lot of character—original hardwood floors, high ceilings, and a little balcony that overlooks the street. Rent is the biggest monthly expense, but it's manageable as long as I'm careful with the rest of my budget. I've been there for almost two years now, and while I've considered looking for something else, I've come to really appreciate the quiet and the sense of community here. It's not the most modern place, but it feels like home, and I don't want to move just for the sake of it. I think I've learned that home isn't always about the size or the location—it's about the comfort and the peace it brings, even if it's not perfect.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Madeline Jensen: Over the past year, my bills have had their ups and downs, mostly tied to the seasons and my own financial situation. In the winter, heating costs went up a bit, which was a surprise because I didn't realize how much the old furnace in the building actually cost to run. I also had to pay for a new laptop in the spring, which was a bigger expense than I expected. Then there were the months when I was feeling really down and spent more on takeout or small things to comfort myself, which added up. On the flip side, during the summer, I used less electricity for heating, and I managed to save a little by cooking at home more. I also noticed that my grocery bills fluctuated depending on whether I was buying in bulk or just going with what I needed week to week. It's been a learning experience, honestly. I've started tracking everything more closely, and I'm trying to be more mindful of how my spending changes with the seasons and my mood. It's not always easy, but I'm getting better at adjusting and staying within my means.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family's support and my relationship with social media have shaped my emotional well-being. Talking about my family reminded me of how important it is to have people who believe in you, even when you're struggling to believe in yourself. My mother's unwavering support and my sister's practical help have been lifelines during tough times, and I'm grateful for their presence in my life. At the same time, discussing my use of social media made me realize how much I've avoided it—not because I don't want to connect, but because I've found it overwhelming and often unfulfilling. I've come to see that staying connected doesn't always require being online; sometimes, it's the simple act of calling a friend or showing up for someone that matters most. These conversations helped me appreciate the balance between leaning on my family and setting boundaries with technology, both of which are essential for my mental health and sense of self.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Madeline Jensen: I try to save in small, consistent ways, even if it's not a lot. I have a savings account that I contribute to every month, usually from whatever I have left after paying rent, groceries, and utilities. It's not a huge amount—maybe $100 to $200 a month—but I think it's important to have that buffer, just in case something unexpected comes up. I also set aside a little money each time I get a paycheck or even from the occasional gig I do, like tutoring or helping with Spanish lessons. I know it's not much, but I've learned that saving doesn't have to be about big amounts—it's about making it a habit, even if it's just a few dollars at a time. I used to think of saving as something only wealthy people could do, but now I see it as part of being responsible with what I have. It's not perfect, and there are months when I don't save as much as I'd like, but I'm trying to be more intentional about it. After all, it's not just about money—it's about building a sense of security, even in small ways.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Madeline Jensen: For me, saving has mostly been about having a rainy day fund, especially since I've been through periods of uncertainty with my job search. I don't have any big savings set aside for something like a home right now—it just doesn't feel like the right time. Instead, I focus on building a small emergency fund so that if something unexpected comes up, like a medical bill or a sudden repair, I don't have to rely on my mother or put everything on hold. I've also been trying to save a little for my Spanish classes, since I want to continue learning even if I'm not in a formal program. It's not about having a lot, but about being prepared for the little things that can throw you off track. I think that's something I've learned through all of this—how to be realistic about what I can save and what I need to prioritize, even when life doesn't always go as planned.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Madeline Jensen: My occupation has been a bit of a journey over the years. After college, I worked at a local nonprofit focused on environmental conservation, where I helped organize community clean-up events, educated people about sustainable practices, and assisted with grant writing. It was rewarding work, but the pay wasn't great, and the job didn't last long after the organization faced funding cuts. After that, I tried freelancing for a few environmental blogs, writing articles about climate change and sustainability, which was something I was passionate about. But that wasn't stable either, and I found myself struggling to make ends meet. When I dropped out of graduate school, I took a break from working full-time, which was both a relief and a challenge. I've been volunteering part-time at the community center ever since, which has given me a sense of purpose and kept me connected to the people around me. I think the most important part of any job for me has always been the impact it has on others—whether it's through education, advocacy, or simply being there for someone in need. I'm still figuring out what kind of work I want to do long-term, but I know it has to be something that aligns with my values and allows me to make a difference, even in small ways.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Madeline Jensen: I usually worked around 20 to 25 hours a week when I was volunteering at the community center, depending on the month and how many events or programs were happening. It wasn't a regular 9-to-5 schedule, which was both flexible and a bit frustrating. On some weeks, I'd be there almost every day, helping with literacy programs, organizing workshops, or just being a friendly face for the kids and families who came in. Other weeks, I'd only work a few days, especially if I was focusing on job applications or personal projects like my Spanish lessons. I think the biggest challenge was balancing the irregular hours with my own need for structure. I used to feel like I wasn't working enough to be productive, but I've come to see that even part-time work, especially one that aligns with my values, can be deeply fulfilling. It's not the same as the full-time jobs I used to have, but it's given me a sense of purpose and connection that I really need right now.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Madeline Jensen: Yes, I actually had a few different jobs and projects over the years, especially when I was trying to figure out what I wanted to do after college. In addition to my work at the nonprofit, I also did some freelance writing for environmental blogs and websites, which I did mostly in the evenings or on weekends. It was flexible, but it also meant I was working irregular hours and often had to juggle multiple projects at once. I even tried tutoring a few students in environmental science on the side, which was both challenging and rewarding. At one point, I was also helping a local artist with a sustainability-themed art installation, which was a completely different kind of work but one that I really enjoyed. Looking back, it was a bit overwhelming trying to do so many things at once, but it also gave me a chance to explore different interests and see what I was truly passionate about. I think that experience taught me that I don't need to stick to one path—sometimes, trying different things helps you find your way, even if it takes longer than you'd like.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my emotional well-being and financial stability are intertwined, and how both have shaped my recent experiences. Talking about my stress levels, coping strategies, and how I manage my monthly budget reminded me of the importance of small, consistent efforts in maintaining balance. I've learned that healing isn't about fixing everything at once—it's about showing up for myself, even on the hardest days. I've also come to appreciate the support I receive from my family, even when it's not always easy to ask for help. These conversations helped me see that staying connected, whether through real-life interactions or mindful financial planning, is essential for my sense of stability and peace. I'm still learning, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made, even if it's not always easy.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Madeline Jensen: In total, my household income last month was pretty limited—mostly from the volunteer work I do at the community center, which doesn't pay much, and a few small gigs I've taken on here and there, like tutoring or helping with Spanish lessons. I also received some financial support from my mother when things got really tight, which I'm grateful for, but I know I can't rely on that forever. I've been trying to be more careful with my money, tracking my expenses and setting aside small amounts for savings, but it's still a struggle. I don't make a lot, and I know that's not ideal, but I'm trying to focus on what I can control—like staying healthy, learning new things, and staying connected with the people who matter most. I think it's important to be realistic about where I am financially, even if it doesn't feel like enough.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Madeline Jensen: I don't have a traditional workplace in the way most people do, which is something I've had to get used to. My 'workplace' is really just the community center where I volunteer, and even that isn't a nine-to-five job. I show up when I can, usually on weekends or afternoons, and help with literacy programs, organize small workshops, or just be there for the kids and families who come in. It's not the kind of job that offers health benefits, paid time off, or a steady paycheck, but it does give me a sense of purpose and connection that I really need. I think part of what makes this experience different is that I'm not just showing up for a job—I'm showing up for people, and that makes all the difference. I've learned that work doesn't always have to be about money or stability; sometimes, it's about the relationships you build and the impact you make, even in small ways.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Madeline Jensen: My relationships at work are pretty informal, which is one of the things I appreciate most about volunteering at the community center. There's no real manager or boss in the traditional sense—more like a team of people who all pitch in and support each other. The person who coordinates the programs, let's call her Lisa, is more of a mentor than a supervisor. She's been there for a while and has a real passion for what she does. She's always encouraging, even when things get busy or chaotic, which is something I really value. As for my coworkers, they're a mix of regular volunteers, staff members, and even some of the kids who come in for the literacy programs. I think what makes it work is that everyone has their own role, but there's also a lot of flexibility. Sometimes I'm helping with a workshop, other times I'm just sitting with a kid who needs someone to talk to. It's not perfect, and there are definitely days when things feel overwhelming, but I've come to see that the relationships I've built here are some of the most meaningful ones I have. It's not about titles or hierarchy—it's about showing up and being there for each other, and that's something I really respect.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Madeline Jensen: My work schedule is pretty unpredictable, which is both a blessing and a challenge. Some weeks I might be there almost every day, especially if there's a big event or a program that needs extra help, and other weeks I might only show up a couple of times if I'm focusing on job applications or personal projects. It's not the kind of schedule that gives you a lot of structure, which can be tough when you're trying to stay motivated or keep a routine. But at the same time, it gives me a lot of flexibility—like if I need to take a day off to go to a therapy session or just have a bad day, I can do that without feeling guilty. I think the unpredictability of it has actually helped me learn to be more adaptable, even if it's not always easy. I don't have the same expectations as someone with a traditional job, and I've come to accept that my work is more about showing up when I can, rather than fitting into a rigid schedule.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Madeline Jensen: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is a work in progress. It's not where I wanted to be, but I'm trying to be realistic about where I am and what I can control. There are days when I feel frustrated by the uncertainty, especially when I see others around me with more stability, but I'm also learning to appreciate what I do have. I know I'm not alone in this—so many people are navigating similar challenges these days. What keeps me going is the sense of purpose I get from volunteering and the small things I'm able to do for myself, like learning Spanish or taking care of my health. I'm not in a rush to fix everything overnight, but I'm trying to build a life that's meaningful, even if it doesn't look like the one I originally imagined. I think that's what matters most—staying grounded, staying connected, and keeping hope alive, even when things feel shaky.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial situation and work experiences have shaped my sense of stability and purpose. Talking about my fluctuating bills, my small savings efforts, and the irregular hours of my volunteer work reminded me of how much I've had to adapt to uncertainty. I've learned that financial stability isn't always about having a lot—it's about being mindful, making small but consistent choices, and finding value in the work I do, even if it's not traditional. It also made me realize how important it is to balance practicality with passion, especially when the path isn't clear. I'm still figuring things out, but I'm trying to be more patient with myself and trust that, even in the messiness, I'm building something meaningful.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Madeline Jensen: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up, though their roles were quite different. My father was an engineer, and he worked full-time for a company that specialized in infrastructure projects. He was pretty dedicated to his job, and I remember him coming home exhausted but always making time for family dinners. My mother, on the other hand, worked part-time as a teacher after my parents' divorce. She had to balance her job with taking care of me, which wasn't always easy. I think she worked at a local school, teaching middle school science, and she was really passionate about it. Even though she wasn't making as much as my father had, she always made sure we had what we needed. Looking back, I realize how much they both sacrificed to provide for me, even during the tough times. It's something I've always been grateful for, and I think it's part of why I ended up pursuing a career in environmental science—because I saw how important their work was, even if it wasn't always in the same field as mine.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Madeline Jensen: My father worked as a structural engineer, designing and overseeing the construction of bridges and other infrastructure projects. His most important duties involved ensuring that the structures he worked on were safe and met all the necessary building codes. He spent a lot of time on-site, working with contractors and reviewing blueprints, and he was always meticulous about the details. I remember seeing him bring home stacks of papers and blueprints, and he'd often explain what he was working on in simple terms, even though I didn't fully understand it at the time. My mother, after the divorce, became a middle school science teacher. Her most important activities involved planning lessons, grading papers, and, most importantly, inspiring her students to love learning. She had a way of making even the most complicated concepts feel accessible, and I think that's why she was so passionate about her job. Even though she was working part-time, she always made sure that her students felt seen and supported. Looking back, I think their work shaped me in ways I didn't realize at the time—it taught me the value of hard work, attention to detail, and the importance of making a difference, even in small ways.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Madeline Jensen: My father worked for a civil engineering firm based in Charleston, South Carolina. It was a mid-sized company that specialized in infrastructure projects like bridges, roads, and public buildings. He was part of a team that designed and oversaw the construction of these structures, making sure they were safe, efficient, and met all the required standards. I remember him talking about how his job required a lot of problem-solving—like figuring out how to build something that could withstand natural disasters or heavy traffic. He also spent a lot of time on-site, meeting with contractors and reviewing blueprints, which he said was one of the most rewarding parts of his job. My mother, on the other hand, worked for a local public school district. She taught middle school science, which meant she spent her days in a classroom, planning lessons, grading papers, and most importantly, helping her students understand complex concepts in a way that made sense to them. She had a real passion for teaching, and I think that's why she was so good at it. Even though she was working part-time after the divorce, she always made sure that her students felt supported and encouraged. Looking back, I think their jobs taught me a lot about responsibility, dedication, and the value of making a difference—whether it was through building something that would last for decades or helping a child understand the world around them.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Madeline Jensen: A few years from now, I hope I'm still in Charleston, but maybe with a little more stability in my life. I don't know if it'll be through a job, a passion project, or something entirely different, but I hope I'm doing work that feels meaningful and aligns with my values. I hope I'm still learning—whether it's through Spanish, new skills, or just understanding myself better. I also hope I'm in a better place mentally, not just surviving but really thriving. I want to be someone who can look back and say I made the most of the time I had, even if it wasn't the path I originally imagined. I hope I'm still connected to the people who matter most—my mother, my sister, my friends, and the community I've come to love. And I hope that whatever comes next, I'm not afraid to take up space, to be seen, and to keep growing, even if it's one small step at a time.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Madeline Jensen: What I value the most in my life is connection—whether it's with family, friends, or the community I live in. I think I've learned that no matter how much I want to be independent or figure things out on my own, I'm at my best when I'm surrounded by people who care about me. I value the small, everyday moments too—the sound of the waves, the smell of fresh coffee, the way my mother always knows how to make me feel better with just a phone call. I also value growth, even when it's slow or messy. I think life is about showing up for yourself and others, even on the days when it's hard. And I value the fact that I'm still here, still trying, still learning, and still hoping for something better—not because I have all the answers, but because I believe in the possibility of change, even when it doesn't look like the path I expected.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how my current financial situation and work experiences have shaped my sense of purpose and stability. Talking about my income, savings, and the nature of my volunteer work reminded me of how much I've had to adapt to uncertainty. I've learned that financial stability isn't always about having a lot—it's about being mindful, making small but consistent choices, and finding value in the work I do, even if it's not traditional. It also made me realize how important it is to balance practicality with passion, especially when the path isn't clear. I'm still figuring things out, but I'm trying to be more patient with myself and trust that, even in the messiness, I'm building something meaningful.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of self-discovery, reflection, and acceptance. It's amazing how much I've learned about myself when I took the time to look back at my childhood, my education, my struggles, and the choices I've made. I never realized how much my parents' influence, my family dynamics, and even the quiet neighborhood I live in now have shaped who I am. It's also been humbling to acknowledge the times I felt lost or uncertain, like after dropping out of graduate school or during the long stretches of job searching. But more than anything, this process has reminded me that life doesn't always go as planned, and that's okay. I've come to see that growth often happens in the unexpected moments, and that resilience isn't about being perfect—it's about showing up, even when it's hard. I'm grateful for the people who have supported me along the way, and I'm learning to be kinder to myself as I continue to navigate this path. This interview has given me a clearer picture of where I've been, where I am now, and where I might be headed. It's not always easy to look back, but it's necessary to move forward with a sense of purpose and hope.
